comments.body: I think what we should do here is track pings that aren't successfully sent, and then send them the next time the tool is started, asynchronously. However, we'd have to give each ping a globally unique ID so that we could de-dupe on the server in the cases where we think it wasn't sent but it actually was.

We don't have control of the backend - it's just standard google analytics. But I have seen tools that do something similar to what you're describing. Any un-sent commands are buffered to a file for sending during the next session.

Analytics is generally a best effort thing however; if we lose some (small) portion of our pings, that's ok. It's more a problem when we lose some type preferentially, and end up skewing the data.

getVersionString can return variable width strings, we should probably figure out the spacing here on the fly rather than hard-coding it. Feel free to file a bug on me if you want me to take care of it.
Oh yeah; I was thinking that it was hard-coded to a specific length, but that's just for the first half of the version, not the branch name part.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +86,90 @@    printStatus('''
  ╔════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╗
  ║              Welcome to Flutter! - Flutter version $versionString - https://flutter.io             ║
  ║                                                                                                    ║
  ║ The Flutter tool anonymously reports feature usage statistics and basic crash reports to Google in ║

comments.body: The paranoid in me wants me to suggest that this should default to true and we should set it to false when we know the user has not opted out, instead of the other way around.

This is being used as a per-command suppression, something that would be an additional constraint over and above the opt-out. If they've opt-out, nothing is sent, and if they've suppressed analytics for this specific invocation, nothing is sent.

Generally, we expect people to opt-out or not; `--suppress-analytics` is meant to be used by machine driven systems, like driving some flutter processes from xcode.
Yeah either way is fine. I just like to see these kinds of things be obviously "fail safe".
